courses.subject: MASE
courses.title: Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering I
courses.description: We live in a materials world. Throughout history, human civilization has always been defined by the materials used: from the stone age, bronze age, and iron age. In the modern era, human lives have become even more intertwined with materials. This course will provide an overview of the science and engineering of materials. The first half of the course will introduce fundamental aspects of bonding, crystallography, and microstructures, all of which form the building blocks of all materials. Fundamental concepts including defects, diffusion, and phase diagram will also be introduced. The second half of the course will introduce different classes of materials and their defining characteristics and physical properties: metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers, and composites. It will bring students to the fascinating world of materials across different length scales from atoms to devices and applications, and different time scales from a historical perspective of materials developments at the beginning of civilizations to today’s complex materials.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student is expected to be able to:

1. Understand the basics of materials science, including how they are classified, their bonding, and their structures.
2. Basic understanding of different classes of materials for different applications.
3. Gain awareness of the techno-economic and sustainability aspect in materials.
4. Evaluate the importance of Materials Science in engineering technologies from a broader
context.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1. Historical perspective of materials
Week 2. Atomic Structure and Bonding
Week 3. Crystallography and Structure – Perfection
Week 4. Crystallography and Structure – Imperfection/Defects
Week 5. Diffusion
Week 6. Phase Diagram
Week 7. Kinetics and Phase Transformation
Week 8. Metals and Metal Alloys
Week 9. Ceramic Materials
Week 10. Polymers and Composites
Week 11. Electronic Materials and Semiconductors
Week 12. Optical and Magnetic Materials
Week 13. Economic, Environmental, and Societal Issues in Materials Science and Engineering
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:

1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.

2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: Provided by the course teacher(s) in the respective teaching term.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Materials Science and Engineering, 9th Edition, Willian D. Callister, David G. Rethwisch,
2013, John Wiley & Sons Inc.
2. Introduction to Materials Science for Engineers, James F. Shackleford, 8th Edition, Global Edition

courses.subject: MASE
courses.title: Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering II
courses.description: This course covers how materials are made, materials properties, and the intricate relationship between composition-processing-structures-properties of materials. The first half of the course encompasses mechanical, electrical, thermal, magnetic, and optical properties of materials. Fundamental factors defining materials properties such as chemical composition, processing, and structures will also be discussed in more details. The second half of the course covers materials processing for metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers, and composites. It aims at providing a basic understanding of how materials are made. Students will also be introduced to various applications of each class of materials. This course concludes with forward-looking discussion on the emerging role of AI for materials discovery and development.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student is expected to be able to:

1. Understand the basics of how materials are made, and the different available tools for making them.
2. Achieve broad understanding of different properties in a material: electrical, thermal, optical, and mechanical.
3. Understand the fundamental factors behind material properties: structure-property relationships.
4. Gain insights on the evolution of materials and materials development, including the age of AI-assisted materials discovery.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1. Composition-processing-structures-properties of Materials
Week 2. Mechanical properties
Week 3. Electrical properties
Week 4. Thermal properties
Week 5. Optical and Magnetic properties
Week 6. Materials Failure Analysis and Prevention
Week 7. Materials Synthesis, Processing, Characterization: Metals and Ceramics
Week 8. Materials Synthesis, Processing, Characterization: Semiconductors
Week 9. Materials Synthesis, Processing, Characterization: Polymers and Composites
Week 10. Energy Materials
Week 11. Functional Materials
Week 12. Materials Research and Development
Week 13. AI-driven Materials Discovery

courses.subject: MASE
courses.title: Materials Laboratory
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with basic hands-on experience in materials processing. Throughout the course, students will be introduced to 5 different sections, namely metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers, and composites. Each of the sections will provide hands-on experience on materials composition, materials processing, and basic structural features of materials. Students will also be encouraged to understand the intricate relationship of structure-property relationship in each section. This course concludes with a hands-on session of technological materials (i.e., simple electronic gadgets) to understand how different classes of materials are combined to provide multi-functional properties in our modern devices.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student is expected to be able to:

1. Gain hands on experience on how materials are made
2. Possess basic skills in materials characterization
3. Have a basic understanding of how composition and processing affects structure and properties
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1) (PHY) Introduction/Error Analysis Lecture
Week 2) (PHY) Error Analysis Lecture
Week 3) (PHY) Measurement of Viscosity (Homework due on Error Analysis)
Week 4) (EE) Microstructure of Materials (need optical microscope/polarized light microscope)
Week 5) (EE) Electric Fields and Equipotentials in Conductive Materials
Week 6) (EE) Conductive Heat Transfer in Materials
Week 7) (EE) Electrical Properties of Materials (4-probe measurements)
Week 8) Lab reports and presentations 1
Week 9) (CHEM) Electrogravimetry: Determination of Copper Content in Metal Alloy
Week 10) (CHEM) Density Measurements of Liquid and Determination of Solubility of NaCl
Week 11) (CHEM) Silicon Oxygen Compounds and Silicon Polymers
Week 12) (CHEM) Identification of Compounds by Chemical Tests
Week 13) Lab reports and presentations 2

courses.subject: MASE
courses.title: Introduction to Polymer Science
courses.description: This introductory course provides a comprehensive overview of polymer science, emphasizing the fundamental principles that underpin the behavior and applications of polymers. Students will explore the intricate relationships between chemical structures, polymer synthesis methods, characterization techniques, and the physical and chemical properties of polymers. The course will also cover a wide array of polymer applications across multiple sectors, including energy, biomaterials, food packaging, lightweight electric vehicles, and construction. Furthermore, the impact of polymers on the ecosystem, strategies for reducing plastic waste, and the development of sustainable materials will be discussed.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student is expected to be able to:

1. Explain the fundamental concepts and classifications of polymers.
2. Recognize the importance of molecular weight and its distribution in polymers, along with the various methods for measurement.
3. Understand the fundamental principles of different polymerization methods, including step-growth and chain-
growth mechanisms (free radical and ionic polymerization).
4. Describe the basic chain conformations of polymers in solution and understand the concept of viscosity in polymer solutions.
5. Understand thermodynamic principles in polymer solutions, including polymer-solution interactions and the Flory-
Huggins theory.
6. Distinguish between amorphous and semi-crystalline polymers and explore the viscoelastic properties of polymers using relevant models.
7. Appreciate the diversion applications of polymer in various industries.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1. Introduction and Basic Concepts
Week 2. Step-Growth Polymerization
Week 3. Chain-Growth Polymerization – Free Radical Polymerization
Week 4. Chain-Growth Polymerization – Ionic and Coordination polymerization
Week 5. Copolymer and Copolymerization
Week 6. Polymer Conformation in Solution
Week 7. Molar Mass and Molar Mass Distribution
Week 8. Dynamics of Dilute Polymer Solutions
Week 9. Thermodynamics of Regular Solutions
Week 10. Amorphous and Crystalline Polymers
Week 11. Glass and Melting Transitions
Week 12. Linear Viscoelasticity
Week 13. Polymers and Environment

courses.subject: MASE
courses.title: Fundamentals of Inorganic Materials Processing
courses.description: This course aims to introduce you to various processes for fabricating inorganic materials. It covers conventional manufacturing processes such as metalworking, forming, casting, ceramics sintering, as well as advanced processes (top-down and bottom-up approaches) to produce nanostructured inorganics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student is expected to be able to:

1. Explain the basic concepts, mechanisms, design and applications of metal forming, and its role in manufacturing processes.
2. Apply basic concepts of alloy solidification to commercial casting processes and predict microstructures and element segregation.
3. Identify the role of machining in manufacturing and the importance of cutting tool materials.
4. List, discuss, apply and assess process of ceramics materials
5. The fundamental of sintering of ceramics.
6. Analyze microstructure -property -structure relationship of ceramic.
7. Define and explain Atomic -,nano -, micro -structure, properties of typical inorganic materials.
8. Introduction of fabrication of nanomaterials, including various top down and bottom-up processes.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction of the courses
Week 2: Metal casting
Week 3: Metal forming
Week 4: Metal machining
Week 5: Ceramics processing
Week 6: Sintering 1
Week 7: Sintering 2
Week 8: Introduction of processing nanofabrications
Week 9: Top down approach 1
Week 10: Top down approach2
Week 11: Bottom up approach 1
Week 12: Bottom up approach 2
Week 13: Cases studies

2. -Groover MP, Principles of Modern Manufacturing, Wiley International, Fifth Edition., 2013
3. M. Barsoum, Fundamentals of Ceramics, IOP publishing Ltd, 2003
4. Nanostructures and Nanomaterials -Synthesis, Properties and Applications, Cao Guozhong and Wang Ying, World Scientific Publishing,2nd edition,2011
5. Nanomaterials: An Introduction to Synthesis, Properties and Applications, Dieter,Vollath, Wiley, 2008

courses.subject: MASE
courses.title: Technology, Society and Engineering Practice
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a broad understanding about the significance and impact of science and technology to the human society, and about the roles and responsibilities of researchers and engineers in the fast-changing world. Topics to be covered include, but not limited to, Technology Evolution and Innovation; Social and Economic Development; Environment and Sustainability; Human Factors and Ethics in Engineering Design; Intellectual Properties. Through diverse learning activities, students will receive training in communication skills, project management, and teamwork, and guidance on career preparation and development. A primary goal of this course is to imbue students with a sense of social responsibility contributing to the betterment of mankind.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ELEG2601
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1. analyze and explain the impact of technology on the society and the environment.
2. recognize and appreciate the contributions of researchers and engineers to the society
3. appreciate the design and innovation aspects of engineering profession
4. acquire the skills and tools to manage engineering projects
5. learn the skills for working in a team
6. understand and state the value of being an ethical engineer and a responsible citizen
courses.course_syllabus:
Relation between science and engineering and their contributions
Technology development: history and future trends
Social and economic development in relation to technology
Engineering project management
Environment, energy, standards and regulatory issues
Engineering ethics
Good engineers and engineer leaders
Entrepreneurship, business, IP and enterprise management
Economic development in GBA, China and the world
